summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorney Maurene Comey and defense attorney Nicolas Bourtin regarding a grand jury subpoena and the process for closing financial accounts related to Jeffrey Epstein. The emails discuss coordination on account closures, production of financial records, and scheduling calls as part of the ongoing investigation.

persons.name: Nicolas Bourtin
persons.context: Attorney corresponding with the U.S. Attorney's office regarding the closure of financial accounts related to Epstein and compliance with a grand jury subpoena.

persons.name: Maurene Comey
persons.context: Prosecutor from the Southern District of New York leading communication about the grand jury subpoena, account closures, and investigation coordination.

persons.name: Gillian P. Seaman
persons.context: Attorney at Sullivan & Cromwell LLP copied on emails, involved in sending a hard drive with data related to the subpoena.

connections.description: Prosecutor and defense attorney coordinating on grand jury subpoena compliance and financial account closures related to Epstein.
Both are attorneys, with Seaman copied on correspondence and assisting with document production.
Seaman sends a hard drive with subpoenaed data to prosecutor Comey, indicating a document production relationship.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoena Issued
events.description: A grand jury subpoena was issued, likely targeting financial records related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Formal Keep-Open Letter Sent
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's office sent a formal letter requesting certain financial accounts be kept open for one month as part of the investigation.

events.title: Scheduling Call for Investigation Discussion
events.description: Prosecutor Comey and attorney Bourtin schedule a call to discuss subpoenaing additional records from other Epstein-related accounts.

locations: St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was actively investigating financial accounts related to Jeffrey Epstein in October-November 2019.
Prosecutors requested that certain financial accounts be kept open for investigation purposes, then later authorized their closure.
A grand jury subpoena was issued on October 3, 2019, targeting financial records, with coordination between prosecutors and defense attorneys.
The investigation involved multiple accounts, with some in the name of entities where Epstein was the authorized signer.
Sensitive financial data was transmitted via password-protected hard drive between legal parties.
